    }
    for(int i=0;i<10;i++){
        if(m.find(i)!=m.end()){

            if(result[i]<result[j]){
                swap(result[i],result[j]);
            }
        }
    }
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/* Given a positive integer n, return a sorted vector that has the odd numbers in collatz sequence. The Collatz conjecture is a conjecture in mathematics that concerns a sequence defined as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1. Note: 1. Collatz(1) is {1}. 2. returned vector sorted in increasing order. <|endoftext|>/*
Create a function that returns true if the last character
of a given string is an alphabetical character and is not
a part of a word, and false otherwise.
Note: "word" is a group of characters separated by space.

Examples:
cehck_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pie")  false
cehck_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pi e")  true
cehck_if_last_char_is_a_letter("apple pi e ")  false
cehck_if_last_char_is_a_letter("")  false 
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
bool cehck_if_last_char_is_a_letter(string txt){
    int len = txt.length();
    if(len == 0)
        return false;
    if(txt[len-1] == 'a')
        return true;
    if(txt[len-1] == 'e')
        return true;
    if(txt[len-1] == 'i')
        return true;
    if(txt[len-1] == 'o')
        return true;
    if(txt[len-1] == 'u')
        return true;
    return false;
}

Return only positive numbers in the vector.

{2, 5, 6}
>>> get_positive({5, 3, -5, 2, -3, 3, 9, 0, 123, 1, -10})
{5, 3, 2, 3, 9, 123, 1}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> get_positive(vector<float> l){
    vector<float> positive;
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){
        if(l[i]>0){
            positive.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    return positive;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double x=0, y=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        if (xs[i]!=0)
        {
            x=xs[i];
            break;
        }
    }
    for (i=xs.size();i>0;i--)
    {
        if (xs[i]!=0)
        {
            y=xs[i-1];
            break;
        }
    }
    return x;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
This function takes a vector l and returns a vector l' such that
l' is identical to l in the indicies that are not divisible by three, while its values at the indicies that are divisible by three are equal
to the values of the corresponding indicies of l, but sorted.
>>> srot_third({1, 2, 3})
{1, 2, 3}
>>> srot_third({5, 6, 3, 4, 8, 9, 2})
{2, 6, 3, 4, 8, 9, 5}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<int> srot_third(vector<int> l){
    vector<int> l1;
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){
        if(l[i]%3==0){
            l1.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    sort(l1.begin(),l1.end());
    vector<int> l2(l1.size());
    for(int i=0;i<l1.size();i++){
        l2[i]=l1[i];
    }
    return l2;
}

}

int add(vector<int> lst){
